title: Stockland takes hit on GFC mall acquisition
text:
In a sign of the times, Stockland sold a suburban mall on Sydney's lower north shore for $3 million less than it paid for it over 12 years ago, just before the global financial crisis.

The diversified property giant, in the midst of a $500 million divestment of non-core retail assets, sold the Cammeray Square centre to syndicator Fortius for $39.05 million on a yield of 7 per cent.

While the price was above the June 2019 book value of $38 million, Stockland took a capital hit, having agreed to pay "approximately $42 million" for the mall in April 2007 when it was under development by Hamptons Development Group.

Cammeray Square opened in 2008 as part of a mixed-use development.

By the time Stockland took possession of the 5000 square metre, four-level property in August 2008, retail values had plunged in the wake of the GFC. In December 2008, the mall, which forms part of a mixed-use development, was valued at just $32.3 million, 23 per cent less than the 2007 purchase price.

It declined further to $29.8 million by December 2010 but then began to recover as commercial real estate values globally rebounded, rising to $32 million in 2014, and $45.5 million in December 2015 and $49 million in December 2016
description: Stockland purchased Cammeray Square for $42 million in 2007. By late 2008 it was valued at $32.3 million
